note.text: Patient presents with hypotension (MAP 59 mmHg), increasing risk of contrast-induced nephropathy.
eGFR of 59 mL/min/1.73m² indicates CKD, warranting renal protective measures.
Emergency admission for chest pain necessitates prompt evaluation, but patient safety is paramount.
ACR guidelines recommend hydration and risk assessment for contrast media administration in patients with compromised renal function and hemodynamic instability.
Carotid CTA protocol is not indicated for the current clinical presentation.

detail.description: Prioritize hemodynamic stabilization before contrast-enhanced imaging, aiming for MAP > 65 mmHg to mitigate contrast-induced nephropathy risk.
If CT Pulmonary Angiography (CTA PE) is essential, implement pre-hydration with isotonic saline and consider a reduced or split contrast dose protocol with a lower injection rate.

Evaluate the clinical necessity of CTA PE by assessing pre-test probability (e.g., Wells score) and consider alternative imaging modalities like V/Q scan if suspicion is low or contrast administration is contraindicated.
Obtain baseline renal labs immediately prior to contrast administration and plan for post-procedure creatinine monitoring (24-48 hours).

resource.name: CTChestAngioPulmonaryEmbolism
resource.title: CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE)
resource.description: CT angiography timed for pulmonary arterial phase (6–13 sec post-contrast) to evaluate pulmonary arteries for embolism.

action.title: Contrast Dose
action.description: Weight-based; ~100–150 mL iodinated contrast (300 mg I/mL); follow ACR Manual.

action.title: Renal Safety Notes
action.description: Ensure contrast-to-eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min); if eGFR <30, consider non-contrast alternatives or weigh risks carefully.
